'''Aerospace Valley''' is a [[France|French]] [[Business cluster|cluster]] of [[aerospace engineering]] companies and research centres. The cluster is located in the regions of [[Occitanie]] and [[Nouvelle Aquitaine]] in the southwest of France and is mainly concentrated in and around the cities of [[Bordeaux]] and [[Toulouse]].
The over 500 affiliated companies (including [[Airbus]], [[Air France|Air France Industries]] and [[Dassault Aviation]]) are responsible for some 120,000 jobs in the aviation and space flight industries. In addition, some 8,500 researchers are active within the affiliated companies and institutions.<ref name="EACP">[http://www.eacp-aero.eu/index.php?id=26 European Aerospace Cluster Partnership: Aerospace Valley]</ref>
The cluster's stated aim is to create 40,000 - 45,000 new jobs by 2026.<ref>[http://www.aerospace-valley.com/en/the-cluster/presentation.html Aerospace Valley: Presentation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821192309/http://www.aerospace-valley.com/en/the-cluster/presentation.html |date=August 21, 2009 }}</ref> Since its inception in 2005, the cluster has initiated some 220 research projects with a total budget of 460 million euros, including 204 million euros in government funding.<ref name="EACP" />
The headquarters of Aerospace Valley is located in Toulouse. Chair of the cluster is [[Jean-Marc Thomas]], who is also vicechair of Airbus France. Key locations of the cluster include:
* The "Aerospace Campus" in Toulouse with the aviation schools [[Institut Supérieur de l'Aéronautique et de l'Espace|ISAE]] (a merger of [[École nationale supérieure de l'aéronautique et de l'espace|SUPAERO]] and [[École nationale supérieure d'ingénieurs de constructions aéronautiques|ENSICA]]) and [[École Nationale de l'Aviation Civile|ENAC]] and over 1000 researchers at [[Office National d'Etudes et de Recherches Aerospatiales|ONERA]], [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique|CNRS]], and [[Centre national d'études spatiales|CNES]], among others. The [[Paul Sabatier University|Université Paul Sabatier]], [[Institut National des Sciences Appliquées de Toulouse|INSA Toulouse]], and [[Institut National Polytechnique de Toulouse|INPT]] are also part of this concentration of research and training facilities in and around Toulouse. * A new aerospace research laboratory of the [[French Institute for Research in Computer Science and Automation|INRIA]] in [[Bordeaux]] * A research centre adjacent to [[Turbomeca]] in [[Bordes, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Bordes]] for aerospace fuel research * An experimental centre in [[Tarbes]] to study better ways of dismantling civil and military aircraft. Aerospace Valley is a member of the [[European Aviation Clusters Partnership]] and of [[Institut au service du spatial, de ses applications et technologies]].
{| |[[File:Airbus Toulouse plant entrance DSC02696.jpg|thumb|650px|left|[[Airbus]] plant in [[Toulouse]] ]] |}
==See also== [[Image:AFI 03 2016 Air-Cobot in hangar.png|thumb|right|[[Air-Cobot]] is an Aerospace Valley project with the purpose to develop a collaborative mobile [[robot]] to inspect [[aircraft]] during [[Aircraft maintenance|maintenance]].]] * [[Air-Cobot]], project of the Aerospace Valley cluster * [[French space program]]
==References== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091222033817/http://www.aerospace-valley.com/docs/site/plaquette-aerospace-an-23-05.pdf Aerospace Valley brochure] <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.aerospace-valley.com/ Website of Aerospace Valley]

'''Ajka Crystal''' is a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[Lead glass|crystal]] manufacturer. Created in 1878 by Bernard Neumann.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ajka Crystal-About Us|url=http://ajka-crystal.hu/en/aboutus}}</ref> The company, one of the biggest in Central Europe produces unique, handmade pieces of glass art.<ref>{{cite web |title=CrystALaCarte - About Ajka Crystal |url=http://www.crystalacarte.com/about-ajka-crystal.asp}}</ref> Ajka Crystal also goes under the name of "The Romanov Collection" in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Romanov Collection |url=http://www.theromanovcollection.com/collections/wine-glasses/products/elizabeth-crystal-wine-stem-cobalt}}</ref> Ajka Crystal ships 90% of the factory's total production - both in tableware (stemware, tumblers etc...) and in giftware (vases, bowls) is exported for world-famous brands such as Wedgwood, Tiffany's, Rosenthal, Waterford Crystal, Polo Ralph Lauren, Christian Dior, Moser and other high end French Crystal Manufacturers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Decorator Brochure Index |url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:pfcG5JEi538J:cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/0048/8972/files/Designer_Brochure.pdf?85+ajka+crystal+also+manufactures+glass+for+waterford&hl=en&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESghestOtLMp-XNvOuLeTD3JQdddjwy_u0jmxBKmL7v6Tlhfq-dSSlD57YIeH2r-zNzeY7tdrEgQ-6lCl-eF7lsZs7S4F1QQf_5zfgM9BUO9VakBrHWVzj9UcOyo8r2Ma0plelgv&sig=AHIEtbTYRVSa-hRwSRLcn1N73ioDUX1i_A}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fotex.eu/page/companies/ajka |title=FOTEX Holding SE |deadurl=yes |accessdate=14 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102020630/http://www.fotex.eu/page/companies/ajka |archivedate=2 January 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Ajka Crystal is located in [[Ajka]], [[Hungary]].
Ajka Crystal's online webshop (CrystALaCarte.com) was established in 2003, with the widest selection of lead crystal products for both retail and wholesale.<ref>{{cite web |title=CrystALaCarte.com - Ajka Crystal Online Store |url=http://www.crystalacarte.com/}}</ref>

second stage, unknown | accuracy = | launch_platform = surface vessels | transport = }} '''Alfa''' was the designation of an Italian [[ballistic missile]] program that started in 1971 under the control of the GRS (Gruppo di Realizzazione Speciale Interforze). Starting as a development effort for a study on efficient solid-propellant rockets, the Alfa rocket was planned as a two-stage rocket. Test launches with an upper stage mockup took place between 1973 and 1975, from [[Salto di Quirra]].{{cite web|url=http://www.friends-partners.org/partners/mwade/lvs/alfa.htm|title=Alfa|publisher=astronautix.com|accessdate=6 October 2013}} The Alfa was {{convert|6.5|m}} long and had a diameter of {{convert|1.37|m}}. The first stage of the Alfa was {{convert|3.85|m}} long and contained 6 t of solid rocket fuel. It supplied a thrust of 232 [[Newton (unit)|kN]] for a duration of 57 seconds. It could carry one tonne warhead for a range of 1,600 kilometres (990 mi), placing [[European Russia]] and Moscow in range from the [[Adriatic Sea]]. [[Italy]] has been active in the space sector since 1957, conducting launch and control operations from the [[Luigi Broglio Space Centre]]. The advanced Scout and [[Vega launcher]]s currently used by the [[European Space Agency]] (ESA) derive their technological basis partially from Alfa studies. {{about|a newborn's bed|the medieval helmet|bascinet}} [[Image:Walraversijde50.jpg|thumb|Modern reproduction of a medieval cot and [[Toy rattle|rattle]], c. 1465]] [[Image:Bassinet.JPG|thumbnail|Movable, but not portable, home bassinet]] [[Image:HRBassinet.JPG|thumb|[[wikt:rooming-in care|Rooming-in]] bassinet]] [[File:Indian cradle.jpg|thumb|A wooden cradle from India]] A '''bassinet''', '''bassinette''', or '''cradle''' is a [[bed (furniture)|bed]] specifically for [[babies]] from birth to about four months. Bassinets are generally designed to work with fixed legs or casters, while cradles are generally designed to provide a rocking or gliding motion. Bassinets and cradles are distinguished from '''Moses baskets''' and '''carry cots''', which are designed to be carried and sit directly on the floor or furniture. After four months, babies are often transferred to a [[infant bed|crib]] (North American usage) or [[infant bed|cot]] (UK usage). In the [[United States]], however, the [[bedside sleeper]] is the prevalent option, since they are generally bigger, recommended up to 6 months, and often used up to a year.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}}
==Design== A bassinet is typically a basket-like structure on free-standing legs, often with casters.<ref name="auto">[https://books.google.com/books?id=ngNLqqYO9oUC&pg=PA71&dq=bassinet+cradle&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPquHCt-PJAhXINT4KHdDPDXQQ6AEINjAB#v=onepage&q=bassinet%20cradle&f=false Injury Prevention for Children and Adolescents: Research, Practice, and Advocacy], Karen DeSafey Lille, Ed. 2006. p.71.</ref> A cradle is typically set in a fixed frame, but with the ability to rock or glide.<ref name="auto"/>
==Use== Bassinet usage in the United States nearly doubled to 20% from 1992-2006.<ref name="auto1">Pike, Jodi, and Rachel Y. Moon. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2575771/ “Bassinet Use and Sudden Unexpected Death in Infancy.”] The Journal of Pediatrics 153.4 (2008): 509–512.</ref> Greater than 45% of babies up to two months used a bassinet.<ref name="auto1"/> By 5–6 months, however, fewer than 10% of babies sleep in bassinets.<ref name="auto1"/> In a hospital environment, a special form of [[Seal (mechanical)|sealed]] bassinet is used in a [[neonatal intensive care unit]].
On many long-haul flights, most airlines provide a bassinet (which is attached to a bulkhead) to adults travelling with an infant, i.e., a child under the age of two. The use of the bassinet is restricted by the infant's size and weight.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flyingwithababy.com/essential-airline-bassinet-information-chart/|title=Airplane Bassinet Seats: A Guide To Airline Bassinet Seat Restrictions|author=|date=1 February 2013|website=flyingwithababy.com}}</ref> These need to be requested in advance with the airline. However, most USA and Canadian airlines have bassinet policies with mean they are only allocated at the airport gate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aa.com/i18n/travel-info/special-assistance/traveling-children.jsp|title=Traveling with children & while pregnant - Special assistance - American Airlines|author=|date=|website=www.aa.com}}</ref><ref name="qantas">[http://www.lufthansa.com/us/en/Children-on-board#ancAbT1 Example of airline travel information regarding children and infants], [[Lufthansa]]</ref><ref name="pic">{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/theblythespirit/1011910419/|title=Flickr|author=|date=|website=Flickr}}</ref>
Research has shown that the [[mattress]] influences [[Sudden infant death syndrome|SIDS]] outcomes; a firm mattress lowers SIDS risk.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080720022617/http://www.sidsandkids.org/pdf/october05_statement.pdf SIDS & Kids] Statement on the use of second hand mattresses</ref>
Some bassinets are designed to rock or swing freely, with many carers finding their child calmed by this action. The process of lulling the child to [[sleep]] may be accompanied by prerecorded or live performance of [[Lullaby|lullabies]].
==Stationary or portable== Although there are many variations, they fall generally into two categories: * light and portable types sometimes called ''Moses baskets'' * [[wikt:sturdy|sturdier]] but less portable cradles
In both cases, they are generally designed to allow the resting baby to be carried from place to place. Within the home, they are often raised on a stand or other surface to reduce back strain when bending over to tend the baby. Wheeled frames to convert a bassinet into a [[baby transport|pram or baby carriage]] are common.
== Rolling == At three or four months of age babies are able to roll over by themselves; this means they could tip the bassinet over, so for safety they must use an [[infant bed]] or [[toddler bed]] instead.
==See also== * [[Baby bedding]] * [[Baby transport]] * [[Neko chigura]]
==References== {{commons category|Cradles}} {{reflist}}

{{Primary sources|article|date=September 2008}}'''BioValley''' is the leading [[life science]] cluster in [[Europe]], founded 1996. It connects academia and companies of three nations in the Upper [[Upper Rhine|Rhine Valley]], namely [[France]], [[Germany]] and [[Switzerland]]. The main objective is the greater research cooperation between companies and academia involved in the life science sectors, including [[pharmacology]], [[biotechnology]], [[nanotechnology]], [[medical technology]], [[chemistry]] and [[agriculture|agricultural]] biotechnology.

[[Jean Case]], Board Member

[[Gail Wilensky]], Ph.D., Board Member | products = Non-invasive mild [[traumatic brain injury]] ([[concussion]]) assessment platform | website = http://brainscope.com/ }}
BrainScope Company, Inc. (BrainScope) is a medical neuro-technology firm using [[artificial intelligence]] to assess a variety of neurological conditions, beginning with mild [[traumatic brain injury]] (mTBI), including [[concussion]]. BrainScope was founded in 2006 and is headquartered in [[Bethesda, Maryland]].
BrainScope's markets include the military, emergency departments, urgent care and occupational medicine centers, and sports at the collegiate and professional levels.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.stripes.com/news/medics-start-using-scanner-that-could-detect-tbi-earlier-1.529566|title=Medics start using scanner that could detect TBI earlier|work=Stars and Stripes|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.kvia.com/news/top-stories/umc-uses-new-equipment-for-brain-care/594019007|title=UMC uses new equipment for brain care|last=Olivas|first=Denise|date=2017-07-27|work=KVIA|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Technology == ''BrainScope One'' uses artificial intelligence and multi-modality to help clinicians rapidly assess mild head-injured patients for structural and functional brain injuries, including concussions, with a non-invasive handheld device and a disposable headset.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wibw.com/content/news/Inside-the-head-game-Washburn-among-first-with-new-BrainScope-device-472274093.html|title=Inside the head game: Washburn among first with new BrainScope device|last=Brunner|first=Melissa|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref>
Using [[Electroencephalography|electroencephalographic]] (EEG) data collected with a disposable headset, ''BrainScope One'' objective biomarkers both predict the likelihood that a patient's structural brain injury would be visible on a [[CT scan]] and assess the likelihood of brain functional impairment by comparing the patient's brain function to that of non-head injured iindividuals.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.technologyreview.com/s/601619/is-this-the-diagnostic-tool-weve-been-waiting-for-in-concussion-testing/|title=This new technology could help clinicians rapidly test for concussions on sidelines and battlefields|last=Orcutt|first=Mike|work=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref> ''BrainScope One'' also includes neurocognitive tests, performed by the patient on the device, and an extensive library of digitized concussion assessments.
An independent validation trial conducted using ''BrainScope One'' determined that the device's sensitivity to "≥1 mL of blood was ... 98.6%" and that its accurate CT-scan predictions can lead to a "reduction in the number of false positives of 33%."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanley|first=Daniel|last2=Prichep|first2=Leslie S.|last3=Bazarian|first3=Jeffrey|last4=Huff|first4=J. Stephen|last5=Naunheim|first5=Rosanne|last6=Garrett|first6=John|last7=Jones|first7=Elizabeth B.|last8=Wright|first8=David W.|last9=O'Neill|first9=John|date=2017-03-31|title=Emergency Department Triage of Traumatic Head Injury Using a Brain Electrical Activity Biomarker: A Multisite Prospective Observational Validation Trial|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/acem.13175|journal=Academic Emergency Medicine|volume=24|issue=5|pages=617–627|doi=10.1111/acem.13175|issn=1069-6563}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huff|first=J. Stephen|last2=Naunheim|first2=Rosanne|last3=Ghosh Dastidar|first3=Samanwoy|last4=Bazarian|first4=Jeffrey|last5=Michelson|first5=Edward A.|date=2017|title=Referrals for CT scans in mild TBI patients can be aided by the use of a brain electrical activity biomarker|url=https://www.ajemjournal.com/article/S0735-6757(17)30409-6/fulltext|journal=The American Journal of Emergency Medicine|language=English|volume=35|issue=11|pages=1777–1779|doi=10.1016/j.ajem.2017.05.027|issn=0735-6757}}</ref>
''BrainScope One's'' technology was created through 21 clinical studies at over 55 clinical sites spanning a decade, contributing to 23 investigator-initiated peer-review journal articles and resulting in 5 FDA clearances.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/us-firm-launches-device-to-rapidly-diagnose-concussion-1.2951121|title=US firm launches device to rapidly diagnose concussion|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en-US}}</ref> ''BrainScope One'' is FDA cleared as an Rx-only device for use on patients 18-85 years of age who have suffered a mild head injury ([[Glasgow Coma Scale]] score of 13-15 and mTBI) within the previous 72 hours. ''BrainScope One'' was originally cleared by the FDA as the Ahead 300 under 510(k) K161068 in September 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfpmn/pmn.cfm?ID=K161068|title=510(k) Premarket Notification|website=www.accessdata.fda.gov|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref> Subsequent modifications to device Indications for Use regarding concussion/mTBI capabilities were FDA cleared under 510(k) K181179 in May 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfpmn/pmn.cfm?ID=K181179|title=510(k) Premarket Notification|website=www.accessdata.fda.gov|access-date=2018-06-27}}</ref>
The company initiated a clinical research study on patients 13-25 years of age in May 2018 as part of its initiative to "introduce a teenage-focused product in the near-term."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180531005299/en/|title=BrainScope Initiates Teenage and Young Adult Multi-Site Clinical Study for Concussion Assessment Product|access-date=2018-06-20|language=en}}</ref>
== Partners == BrainScope has raised over $60 million in private capital and has received $30 million in research contracts, including funding from the [[United States Department of Defense]] and [[General Electric]] and the [[National Football League]] through their Head Health Challenge competition.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bethesdamagazine.com/Bethesda-Beat/2015/Whitman-High-School-Chosen-for-Concussion-Research-Study/|title=Whitman High School Chosen for Concussion Research Study|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> Among the company's private investors are [[Revolution LLC]], an investment firm founded by [[AOL]] co-founder [[Steve Case]]; DBL Partners, a venture capital firm that also backs [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla]] and [[Pandora Radio|Pandora]]; and the [[Maryland Venture Fund]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/08/31/term-sheet-thursday-august-31/|title=Term Sheet -- Thursday, August 31|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dblpartners.vc/portfolio/|title=Portfolio {{!}} DBL Partners|website=www.dblpartners.vc|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170830005824/en/BrainScope-Completes-16-Million-Equity-Fundraise|title=BrainScope Completes $16 Million Equity Fundraise|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}}</ref>
BrainScope's other development partners include [[New York University]] School of Medicine and [[Johns Hopkins University]] and its clinical partners include [[Emory University]], the [[University of Virginia]] and [[Washington University in St. Louis]].<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2017/04/170405112030.htm|title=Quickly assessing brain bleeding in head injuries using new device|work=ScienceDaily|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/health-med-fit/health/working-to-prevent-diagnose-concussions-in-kids/article_69281bbe-c171-5f0b-b701-d64c5984c157.html|title=Working to prevent, diagnose concussions in kids|last=Bernhard|first=Blythe|work=stltoday.com|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref>
== Awards ==
* Winner of the 2017 [[Frost & Sullivan]] Best Practices Award - Traumatic Brain Injury New Product Innovation<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170710006058/en/BrainScope-Receives-Frost-Sullivan-Practices-Award-Traumatic|title=BrainScope Receives Frost & Sullivan Best Practices Award in Traumatic Brain Injury Assessment|access-date=2018-06-26|language=en}}</ref> * Finalist for the 2017 Prix Galien Foundation USA Award for Best Medical Technology Product<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-galien-foundation-debuts-2017-prix-galien-usa-nominees-in-best-biotechnology-product-best-pharmaceutical-product-and-best-medical-technology-categories-300494168.html?tc=eml_cleartime|title=The Galien Foundation Debuts 2017 Prix Galien USA Nominees in "Best Biotechnology Product," "Best Pharmaceutical Product," and "Best Medical Technology" Categories|last=Foundation|first=The Galien|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> * Greater Washington Health & Life Sciences 2017 Innovator of the Year<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.insidenova.com/headlines/greater-washington-innovation-awards-winners-and-finalists-announced/article_bc3c4766-2c21-11e7-ac37-3b5acc110e87.html|title=2017 Greater Washington Innovation Awards winners and finalists announced|work=INSIDENOVA.COM|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}</ref> * Winner of the 2017 Moxie Award for Healthcare<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://moxieaward.com/winners2017/#selected|title=Moxie Award 2017 Winners - {{Infobox radio station | image = CKUA logo.svg | image_size = 170px | name = CKUA | airdate = November 21, 1927 | frequency = [http://www.ckua.com/transmitter-map Various FM frequencies] | area = [[Alberta]] | format = Community Radio | owner = CKUA Radio Foundation | power = see chart | branding = CKUA Radio Network | slogan = ''Music, Story, Connection'' | class = see chart | former_frequencies = [[580 AM|580 kHz]] | website = [http://www.ckua.com/ CKUA] | callsign_meaning = '''C'''anada '''K U'''niversity of '''A'''lberta }} The '''CKUA Radio Network''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] donor-funded community radio network based in [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]]. Originally located on the campus of the [[University of Alberta]] in Edmonton (hence the UA of the call letters), it was the first public broadcaster in Canada. It now broadcasts from studios in downtown Edmonton, and as of fall 2016 out of a studio in Calgary located at the [[National Music Centre]]. CKUA's primary station is CKUA-FM located on 94.9 FM in Edmonton, and the station operates fifteen rebroadcasters to serve the remainder of the province. ==History== CKUA was created in 1927[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/473940910/ "Mercy - Arden collects half a dozen ARIAs"]. ''Edmonton Journal'', Edmonton, Alberta, May 30, 1994, p. 12 through a provincial grant which allowed the University of Alberta's Extension Department to purchase the licence of CFCK. CKUA was also the first radio station to offer educational radio programming, including music concerts, poetry readings, and university lectures. From 1930 to 1931 the station was an affiliate of the [[CNR Radio]] network.[http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/listings_and_histories/radio/histories.php?id=125&historyID=56 CKUA History from the Canadian Communications Foundation] CKUA was operated from 1945 until 1974 by [[Alberta Government Telephones]].[http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/listings_and_histories/radio/listings.php?pt=130&r=59#CKUA-AM CKUA History] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010135950/http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/listings_and_histories/radio/listings.php?pt=130&r=59#CKUA-AM#CKUA-AM |date=2006-10-10 }}, Canadian Communications Foundation The [[crown corporation]], [[Access (TV channel)|Alberta Educational Communications Corporation]] (later known as Access), assumed ownership of the station in 1974. In 1994, Access sold the CKUA network to the non-profit CKUA Radio Foundation for $10.[http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/listings_and_histories/radio/histories.php?id=1009&historyID=57 CKUA-FM history, Canadian Communications Foundation] In 1994 the station won an Alberta Recording Industry Award of Excellence.[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/473940910/ "Mercy - Arden collects half a dozen ARIAs"]. ''Edmonton Journal'', Edmonton, Alberta, May 30, 1994, p. 12 On March 20, 1997 the station went off the air for five weeks due to political squabbles, poor financial management, and attempts at privatization.{{cite book|author=Geo Takach|title=Will the Real Alberta Please Stand Up?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IJSnAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA252|date=1 December 2010|publisher=University of Alberta|isbn=978-0-88864-772-6|page=252}} The station restarted broadcasting on April 25, 1997 after control was given to the public from directors appointed by the provincial government. As of 2005, more than two-thirds of the station's funding came from its listeners in the form of donations. ==Cultural Impact== CKUA is considered a cultural icon by many musicians throughout Canada. The station's practice of supporting local, independent, and non-commercial artists has helped launch the careers of such renowned musicians as [[k.d. lang]], [[Jann Arden]], and [[Bruce Cockburn]]. In addition, CKUA has contributed to the careers of [[Arthur Hiller]], [[Robert Goulet]], and [[Tommy Banks]], among others. Throughout the 1930s an early [[radio drama]] series, ''CKUA Players'', was produced out of the station and broadcast throughout [[Western Canada]] by a network of stations.[https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/english-language-radio-drama/ Radio Drama, English Language], ''Canadian Encyclopedia'', accessed January 23, 2008 ==Programming== CKUA schedules different programs throughout the week and thus can offer many different genres including [[blues]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[R&B]], [[Celtic Music|Celtic]], [[country music|country]], [[classical music|classical]], [[jazz]], [[reggae]], folk, [[hiphop]], [[dance music|dance]], [[funk]], [[rock music|rock]], roots, and [[world music|world]]. ==Historic Music Archive== CKUA's music library boasts one of the largest and most diverse music collections in Canada, with more than 250,000 [[Compact disc|CD]]s and [[Vinyl record#Common formats|LP]]s, including 10,000 [[Gramophone record#Early history|78 rpm]] records, as well as a few [[aluminum disc|aluminium transcription discs]], [[Vinyl record#Common formats|45s]], and other various media formats. ==Broadcast Locations== CKUA was headquartered in the Alberta Block building on [[Jasper Avenue]] in Edmonton starting in 1955. In October, 2012, CKUA moved into its current location in the Alberta Hotel building, with its first broadcast from the new location on October 15, 2012.[http://globalnews.ca/news/294611/ckua-radio-celebrates-new-home-with-ceremonial-record-delivery/ "CKUA Radio celebrates new home with ceremonial record delivery"]. By Caley Ramsay ''Global News'', October 6, 2012 ==Broadcast technics== The station's original transmitter was located at 580 [[kHz]] in Edmonton. It operated at 10,000 watts. Due to its location near the bottom of the AM dial, as well as its transmitter power, it was powerful enough to cover nearly all of Alberta's densely populated area. It added an FM simulcast in 1947. Starting in the 1970s, CKUA built a network of 16 [[FM broadcasting|FM]] repeaters across Alberta. CKUA also broadcasts in western Canada on select cable and satellite providers (such as [[SaskTel]], who carries CKUA across Saskatchewan as a [[Lloydminster]] station). As of February 29, 1996, CKUA became the first radio station in Canada to [[Internet radio|stream]] their broadcast online, and now has upgraded the service to carry an unlimited number of streams. The station currently has more than 250,000 weekly listeners. Because of CKUA's extensive coverage, the station was one of only a handful of broadcasters (another being [[CTV Two Alberta]], formerly Access) to carry the Alberta [[Emergency Public Warning System]]. The provincial government-funded programme provided the station with 12% of its annual income until the contract was lost to an Ottawa firm, Black Coral Inc., in January 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/edmonton/story/2010/01/12/edmonton-ckua-jobs-cut.html |title=Contract loss forces job cuts at CKUA |date= January 12, 2010|work=www.cbc.ca |accessdate= May 20, 2010}} CKUA announced plans to shut down its legacy 580 AM signal, the longest continuously-used AM frequency in Canada, in the spring of 2013. It would have needed to invest as much as $5 million to upgrade the transmitter site to modern standards, an amount it could not afford.[http://www.broadcasting-history.ca/listings_and_histories/radio/listings.php?pt=130&r=59&ac=&former=y#CKUA-AM CKUA-AM history] at [[Canadian Communications Foundation]] However, CKUA did not receive formal approval from the CRTC until September 12, 2013.[http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2013/2013-483.htm Broadcasting Decision CRTC 2013-483], CKUA-FM Edmonton – Deletion of an AM transmitter, ''CRTC'', September 12, 2013 AM 580 went off the air on November 21, 2013, the station's 86th anniversary. ==Current On-Air Personalities== The CKUA program lineup relies on a number of on-air personalities. {{columns-list|colwidth=20em| * Mark Antonelli * Dilbagh Singh Bhangoo ("Baba") * Allison Brock * Bob Chelmick * Lark Clark * Cheryl Croucher * Tom Coxworth * Tony Dillon-Davis * {{Redirect|CNET Networks|the successor online media company|CBS Interactive}} {{Redirect|News.com|the Australian news website|news.com.au}} {{For|Centre National d'Études des Télécommunications (CNET), the research and development centre of France Télécom|France Télécom|Centre national d'études des télécommunications}} {{Infobox website |logo = [[File:cnetlogo.png|150px]] |screenshot = |caption = |url = [https://www.cnet.com/ cnet.com] |commercial = Yes |type = Technology News |registration = Optional |owner = [[CBS Interactive]] |author = [[Halsey Minor]]
Shelby Bonnie |editor = Lindsey Turrentine
Connie Guglielmo |alexa = {{Increase}} 154 ({{as of|2017|03|07|alt=September 2016}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/cnet.com |title= Cnet.com Site Overview | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2016-08-09}} |name = CNET |industry = Journalism |launch date = {{start date and age|1994|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/cnet.com|title=CNET.com WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info - DomainTools|work=[[WHOIS]]|date= |accessdate=2016-09-16}} |current status = Online }} '''CNET''' (stylized as '''c|net''') is an American media website that publishes reviews, news, articles, blogs, podcasts and videos on technology and [[consumer electronics]] globally. Founded in 1994 by [[Halsey Minor]] and Shelby Bonnie, it was the flagship brand of CNET Networks and became a brand of [[CBS Interactive]] through CNET Networks' acquisition in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbscorporation.com/news/prdetails.php?id=3263|title=CBS Corporation to acquire CNET Networks, Inc.|publisher=CBS Corporation| date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=May 15, 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080518032023/http://www.cbscorporation.com/news/prdetails.php?id=3263 |archivedate=May 18, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com/8301-10784_3-9944882-7.html|title= CBS to buy CNET Networks|publisher=CNET|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=May 15, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://dailybriefing.blogs.fortune.cnn.com/2008/05/15/cbs-buying-cnet-in-online-push/|title=CBS buying CNet in online push|publisher=CNN|date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=May 15, 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080517215301/http://dailybriefing.blogs.fortune.cnn.com/2008/05/15/cbs-buying-cnet-in-online-push/ |archivedate=May 17, 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbscorporation.com/news/prdetails.php?id=3503 |title=CBS Corporation completes acquisition of CNET Networks; merges operations into new, expanded CBS Interactive Business Unit |publisher=CBS Corporation |date=June 30, 2008 |accessdate=June 30, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829001159/http://www.cbscorporation.com/news/prdetails.php?id=3503 |archivedate=August 29, 2008 }} CNET originally produced content for radio and television in addition to its website and now uses [[new media]] distribution methods through its [[Internet television|Internet television network]], [[CNET Video]], and its podcast and blog networks. In addition, CNET currently has region-specific and language-specific editions. These include the United Kingdom, Australia, China, Japan, French, German, Korean and Spanish. According to third-party [[web analytics]] providers, [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]] and [[SimilarWeb]], CNET is the highest-read technology news source on the Web, with over 200 million readers per month, being among the 200 most visited websites globally, as of 2015.{{cite web | url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/cnet.com | title=cnet.com Site Overview | publisher=alexa.com | accessdate=June 28, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.similarweb.com/category/news_and_media/technology_news | title=Top 50 sites in the world for News And Media > Technology News | publisher=similarweb.com | accessdate=June 28, 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.similarweb.com/website/cnet.com | title=Cnet.com Analytics | publisher=similarweb.com | accessdate=June 28, 2015}} ==History== {{See also|CBS Interactive}} ===Origins=== [[File:Logo CNET Networks.svg|thumb|left|100px|Logo of CNET Networks prior to acquisition by CBS Interactive]] In 1994, with the help from [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox Network]] co-founder{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalhollywood.com/KeynoteKWendle.html |title=Digital Hollywood Conference |date=September 27, 2000 |accessdate=November 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111103085457/http://www.digitalhollywood.com/KeynoteKWendle.html |archivedate=November 3, 2011 }} Kevin Wendle and former Disney creative associate Dan Baker,{{cite web|url=http://www.cnetnetworks.com/aboutus/history.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050406175002/http://www.cnetnetworks.com/aboutus/history.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 6, 2005 |title=CNET Networks – About Us – History |publisher=CNET Networks |accessdate=June 29, 2007 |df= }} CNET produced four pilot television programs about computers, technology, and the Internet. [[CNET TV]] was composed of ''CNET Central'', ''The Web'', and ''The New Edge''.[http://news.cnet.com/CNET-to-launch-two-new-TV-shows/2100-1023_3-210413.html CNET][http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,286315,00.html Entertainment Weekly] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421153829/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C286315%2C00.html |date=April 21, 2009 }} ''CNET Central'' was created first and aired in [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] in the [[United States]] on the [[USA Network]]. Later, it began airing on USA's sister network [[Syfy|Sci-Fi Channel]] along with ''The Web'' and ''The New Edge''. These were later followed by [[TV.com]] in 1996. Current ''[[American Idol]]'' host [[Ryan Seacrest]] first came to national prominence at CNET, as the host of ''The New Edge'' and doing various voice-over work for CNET. In addition, CNET produced another television technology news program called ''News.com'' that aired on [[CNBC]] beginning in 1999. From 2001 to 2003, CNET operated CNET Radio on the [[Clear Channel Communications|Clear Channel]]-owned [[KKSF (AM)|KNEW]] (910) in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[WAMG|WBPS]] (890) in [[Boston]] and on [[XM Satellite Radio]]. CNET Radio offered technology-themed programming. After failing to attract a sufficient audience, CNET Radio ceased operating in January 2003 due to financial losses.{{cite web|url= http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/stories/2003/01/13/daily60.html|title=CNet pulls plug on radio program|publisher=Silicon Valley / San Jose Business Journal|date=January 16, 2003|accessdate=June 29, 2007}} ===Acquisitions and expansions=== As '''CNET Networks''', the site made various acquisitions to expand its reach across various web platforms, regions, and markets. In July 1999, CNET acquired the [[Switzerland|Swiss]]-based company GDT.{{cite web|url= http://edgar.secdatabase.com/880/95013499006969/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Aug 6, 1999|publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Mar 27, 2013}} GDT was later renamed to CNET Channel.{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/294/0001015577-02-000009.pdf|title=CNET Networks, Form 10-K, Annual Report, Filing Date Apr 1, 2002 |publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}} In 1998, CNET granted the right to Asiacontent to set up CNET Asia and the operation was brought back in December 2000.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519084953/https://www.joomag.com/magazine/18008833685-activation-key-for-mcafee-antivirus-internet-security-mcafee-internet-security-plus-activation-key-/0134078001493015223|title=18008833685 Activation key for Mcafee Antivirus internet security Mcafee internet security - Plus Activation key -|date=19 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/73673/cnet-ziff-davis_merger_leaves_asiacontent_com_wondering|title=CNET-Ziff-Davis Merger Leaves Asiacontent.com Wondering|publisher=}} In January 2000, the same time CNET became CNET Networks,{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/392/95013400000494/filing-main.htm |title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Jan 24, 2000|publisher= secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}} they acquired comparison shopping site [[mySimon]] for $736 million.{{cite web|url= http://edgar.secdatabase.com/1730/95013400001832/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Mar 10, 2000|publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate =Mar 27, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.internetnews.com/ec-news/article.php/289951|title=CNET Acquires mySimon|publisher=InternetNews|date=January 20, 2000|accessdate=January 19, 2008}} In October 2000, CNET Networks acquired [[ZDNet]] for approximately $1.6 billion.{{cite web|url= http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2772/95013400008872/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Oct 27, 2000|publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.informationweek.com/story/IWK20000719S0010|title=Cnet To Buy Ziff Davis|publisher=[[InformationWeek]]|date=July 19, 2000|accessdate=June 29, 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.journalismjobs.com/interview_kohara.cfm |title=Interview With CNETnews.com's Sydnie Kohara |publisher=JournalismJobs.com |date=January 2001 |accessdate=June 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070413070117/http://www.journalismjobs.com/interview_kohara.cfm |archivedate=April 13, 2007 }} In January 2001, [[Ziff Davis]] Media, Inc. reached an agreement with CNET Networks, Inc. to regain the URLs lost in the 2000 sale of Ziff Davis, Inc. to [[SoftBank]] Corp. a publicly traded Japanese media and technology company.{{cite web|url=https://www.joomag.com/magazine/18008833685-activation-key-for-symantec-norton-antivirus-360-2017-norton-activation-online-norton-activate-norton/0452962001493032432? |title=Activation Key Setup for Norton Retail Card |publisher=Norton Antivirus activation key |date=January 23, 2001 |accessdate=January 19, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519041229/https://www.joomag.com/magazine/18008833685-activation-key-for-symantec-norton-antivirus-360-2017-norton-activation-online-norton-activate-norton/0452962001493032432 |archivedate=May 19, 2017 |df= }} In April 2001, CNET acquired TechRepublic Inc., which provides content for IT professionals from [[Gartner|Gartner, Inc.]], for $23 million in cash and stock.{{cite web|url= http://edgar.secdatabase.com/1126/101557701500008/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form 10-Q, Quarterly Report, Filing Date May 14, 2001 |publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}}{{cite web|url= http://sanfrancisco.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2001/04/09/daily5.html|title=CNET acquires TechRepublic for $23 million|publisher=[[San Francisco Business Times]]|date= April 9, 2001|accessdate=January 19, 2008}} On July 14, 2004, CNET announced that it would acquire [[Webshots]], the leading photography website for $70 million ($60 million in cash, $10 million in deferred consideration),{{cite web|url= http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2997/101557704000046/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Jul 21, 2004|publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}} completing the acquisition that same month.{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/25/0001015577-04-000073.pdf|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Aug 9, 2004 |publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013|format=PDF}}{{cite web|url=http://www.paidcontent.org/entry/cnet-acquires-photo-service-webshots-for-70-million |title=CNET Acquires Photo Service Webshots For $70 Million |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206131702/http://www.paidcontent.org/entry/cnet-acquires-photo-service-webshots-for-70-million |archivedate=December 6, 2008 }} In October 2007, they sold Webshots to [[American Greetings]] for $45 million.{{cite web|url= http://pdf.secdatabase.com/1344/0001193125-07-231235.pdf|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Oct 31, 2007|publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013|format=PDF}} In December 2006, James Kim, an editor at CNET, died in the Oregon wilderness. CNET hosted a memorial show and podcasts dedicated to him. On March 1, 2007, CNET announced the public launch of BNET, a website targeted towards business managers. BNET had been running under beta status since 2005.{{cite news|url=http://www.btobonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070301/FREE/70301001/1078 |title=CNET Networks rolls out BNET, Web site targeting business managers |publisher=BtoB Magazine |date=March 1, 2007 |accessdate=June 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928142542/http://www.btobonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20070301%2FFREE%2F70301001%2F1078 |archivedate=September 28, 2007 |df= }} On May 15, 2008 it was announced that [[CBS Corporation]] would buy CNET Networks for [[United States dollar|US$]]1.8 billion.{{cite web|url= http://pdf.secdatabase.com/2034/0001193125-08-116630.pdf|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date May 15, 2008|publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbscorporation.com/news/prdetails.php?id=3263|title=CBS Corporation to acquire CNET Networks, Inc.|publisher=CBS Corporation |date=May 15, 2008|accessdate=May 15, 2008|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080518032023/http://www.cbscorporation.com/news/prdetails.php?id=3263|archivedate=May 18, 2008}} On June 30, 2008, the acquisition was completed.{{cite web|url=http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2813/119312508147399/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form POS AM, Filing Date Jul 7, 2008|publisher= secdatabase.com|accessdate=Mar 27, 2013}} Former CNET properties are now part of [[CBS Interactive]]. CBS Interactive now owns many [[second-level domain|domain]] names originally created by CNET Networks, including [[download.com]], downloads.com, upload.com, news.com, search.com, [[TV.com]], [[MP3.com|mp3.com]], chat.com, computers.com, shopper.com, [[radio.com]], com.com, and cnet.com. On September 19, 2013 CBS Interactive launched a [[Spanish language]] sister site under the name CNET en Español.{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-30677_3-57603575-244/cnet-en-espa-ol-is-here-bienvenidos/|author=Lindsey Turrentine|title=CNET en Español is here. Bienvenidos|publisher=CNET News|date=September 19, 2013|accessdate=January 30, 2014}} It focuses on topics of relevance primarily to Spanish-speaking technology enthusiasts. The site offered a "new perspective" on technology and is under the leadership of managing editor Gabriel Sama.{{cite news|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-30677_3-57599633-244/meet-the-man-who-will-run-cnet-en-espanol/|author=Lindsey Turrentine|title=Meet the man who will run CNET en Español|publisher=CNET News|date=August 22, 2013|accessdate=January 30, 2014}} In March 2014, CNET refreshed its site by merging with CNET UK and vowing to merge all editions of the agency into a unified agency. This merge brought many changes, foremost of which would be a new user interface and the renaming of CNET TV as CNET Video. ==Gamecenter== CNET launched a website to cover [[video games]], CNET Gamecenter, in the middle of 1996.{{cite web | archiveurl=https://archive.is/bZ98c | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/07/technology/basics-sites-keep-up-with-games-and-gamers.html | title=BASICS; Sites Keep Up With Games and Gamers | author=Olafson, Peter | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=December 7, 2000 | archivedate=May 23, 2018 | deadurl=no }} According to the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', it was "one of the first Web sites devoted to computer gaming news".{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523184059/https://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Heavy-Lifting-Begins-for-Cnet-Dot-com-downturn-2951969.php | url=https://www.sfgate.com/business/article/Heavy-Lifting-Begins-for-Cnet-Dot-com-downturn-2951969.php | title=Heavy Lifting Begins for Cnet | date=February 15, 2001 | author=Fost, Dan | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | archivedate=May 23, 2018 | deadurl=no }} It became a leading game-focused website;{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523191403/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/article_28565 | url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/article_28565 | title=Cnet buys ZDnet | date=July 19, 2000 | author=Vaggabond | work=[[Eurogamer]] | archivedate=May 23, 2018 | deadurl=no }} in 1999, ''[[PC Magazine]]'' named it one of the hundred-best websites in any field, alongside competitors [[IGN]] and [[GameSpot]].{{cite journal | author=Willmott, Don | title=The 100 Top Web Sites | date=February 9, 1999 | volume=18 | number=3 | journal=[[PC Magazine]] | page=114 }} According to Gamecenter head Michael Brown, the site received between 50,000 and 75,000 daily visitors by late 2000. In May 2000, CNET founded the Gamecenter Alliance network to bring Gamecenter and four partner websites, including [[Inside Mac Games]], under one banner.{{cite press release | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040811071841/http://reviews.cnet.com/html/aboutcnet/press/2000/051100.html | url=http://reviews.cnet.com/html/aboutcnet/press/2000/051100.html | title=CNET Gamecenter Partners with Premier Gaming Sites to Create Elite Alliance | date=May 11, 2000 | location=[[San Francisco]] | archivedate=August 11, 2004 | publisher=CNET | deadurl=no }} On July 19, 2000, CNET made public its plan to buy [[Ziff-Davis]] and its [[ZDNet]] Internet business for $1.6 billion.{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823063448/https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/20/business/cnet-is-buying-what-remains-of-ziff-davis.html | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/20/business/cnet-is-buying-what-remains-of-ziff-davis.html | title=CNet Is Buying What Remains Of Ziff-Davis | authors=Kuczynski, Alex; Winter, Greg | date=July 20, 2000 | work=[[The New York Times]] | archivedate=August 23, 2010 | deadurl=no }} Because ZDNet had partnered with SpotMedia—parent company of GameSpot—in late 1996,{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523192831/http://adage.com/article/news/ziff-spotmedia-create-mega-site-games/2392/ | url=http://adage.com/article/news/ziff-spotmedia-create-mega-site-games/2392/ | title=Ziff, SpotMedia Create Mega-Site for Games | date=September 19, 1996 | author=Staff | work=[[Ad Age]] | archivedate=May 23, 2018 | deadurl=no }} the acquisition brought both GameSpot and Gamecenter under CNET's ownership.{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041204094044/https://www.theregister.co.uk/2001/02/07/cnet_shuts_gamecenter/ | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2001/02/07/cnet_shuts_gamecenter/ | title=CNET shuts Gamecenter | date=February 7, 2001 | archivedate=December 4, 2004 | author=Smith, Andrew | work=[[The Register]] | deadurl=no }} Later that year, ''[[The New York Times]]'' described the two publications as the "''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]'' of gaming sites". The paper reported that Gamecenter "seem[ed] to be thriving" amid the [[Dot-com bubble|dot-com crash]], with its revenue distributed across [[online advertising]] and an [[Affiliate marketing|affiliate sales program]] with CNET's Game Shopper website, launched in late 1999.{{cite press release | archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180523194546/https://www.thefreelibrary.com/CNET's+Gamecenter.com+Launches+Game+Shopper-a056951387# | url=https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:kLEMpVskOSYJ:https://www.thefreelibrary.com/CNET%2527s%2BGamecenter.com%2BLaunches%2BGame%2BShopper-a056951387+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us | title=CNET's Gamecenter.com Launches Game Shopper | date=October 27, 1999 | publisher=[[PR Newswire]] | location=[[San Francisco]] | archivedate=2018-05-23 | deadurl=no | access-date=2018-11-16 | df= }} Following an almost $400 million loss at CNET as a result of the dot-com crash, the company ended the Gamecenter Alliance network in January 2001.{{cite web | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180523200151/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/article_30103 | url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/article_30103 | title=CNet culls GameCenter | date=February 7, 2001 | author=Bramwell, Tom | archivedate=May 23, 2018 | work=[[Eurogamer]] | deadurl=yes }} On February 7, Gamecenter itself was closed in a redundancy reduction effort, as GameSpot was the more successful of the two sites. Around 190 jobs were cut from CNET during this period, including "at least 20" at Gamecenter, according to the ''San Francisco Chronicle''. Discussing the situation, Tom Bramwell of [[Eurogamer]] reported, "It is thought[...] that very few if any of the website's staff will move sideways into jobs at GameSpot, now the company's other gaming asset." ''[[The Washington Post]]'' later noted that Gamecenter was among the "popular video-game news sites" to close in 2001, alongside [[Daily Radar]].{{cite web | archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180523201714/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/2001/08/03/magazines-whose-time-has-gone/2cfa9df2-1610-4230-a9ed-85a0be911d5e/# | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/business/2001/08/03/magazines-whose-time-has-gone/2cfa9df2-1610-4230-a9ed-85a0be911d5e/ | title=Magazines Whose Time Has Gone | author=Musgrove, Mike | date=August 3, 2001 | work=[[The Washington Post]] | archivedate=2018-05-23 | deadurl=no | access-date=2018-05-23 | df= }} == Malware infection in downloads == With a catalog of more than 400,000 titles, the Downloads section of the website allows users to download popular software. CNET's download.com provides [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Macintosh]] and mobile software for download. CNET claims that this software is free of [[spyware]], but independent sources have confirmed that this is not the case. [[Download.com]] not only hosts software with malware, but their own download wrapper contains [[adware]] and bloatware.{{cite web|url=http://www.virustotal.com/file-scan/report.html?id=5bd70802c051fd95d0d78ac168385cd504705c00526ded2fd5edebdcc32d48f6-1323123804|title=Antivirus scan for 5bd70802c051fd95d0d78ac168385cd504705c00526ded2fd5edebdcc32d48f6 at 2011-12-05 22:23:24 UTC - VirusTotal|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://seclists.org/nmap-announce/2011/5|title=Nmap Announce: C-Net Download.Com is now bundling Nmap with malware!|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.extremetech.com/computing/93504-download-com-wraps-downloads-in-bloatware-lies-about-motivations|title=Download.com wraps downloads in bloatware, lies about motivations - ExtremeTech|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://botcrawl.com/cnet-downloads-a-cesspool-for-privacy-invading-malware/|title=Warning: Download.com (CNET Downloads) A cesspool for privacy invading malware and rogue software - Botcrawl|date=9 December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=5 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.howtogeek.com/198622/heres-what-happens-when-you-install-the-top-10-download.com-apps/|title=Here’s What Happens When You Install the Top 10 Download.com Apps|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://insecure.org/news/download-com-fiasco.html|title=Download.com Caught Adding Malware to Nmap & Other Software|publisher=}} == Dispute with Snap Technologies == In 1998, CNET was sued by Snap Technologies, operators of the education service CollegeEdge, for [[trademark infringement]] relating to CNET's ownership of the domain name Snap.com, due to Snap Technologies [[Cybersquatting|already owning a trademark on its name]].{{cite web|author=Lisa Bowman|url=http://www.zdnet.com/news/snap-crackle-popped-cnet-hit-with-suit-over-portal-name/101041|title=Snap! Crackle! Popped! CNet hit with suit over portal name|publisher=[[ZDNet]] News|date=November 21, 1998 |accessdate=May 11, 2008}} In 2005, Google representatives refused to be interviewed by all CNET reporters for a year after CNET published Google's CEO [[Eric Schmidt]]'s salary, named the neighborhood where he lives, some of his hobbies and political donations.{{cite web| url=http://news.cnet.com/2100-1032_3-5787483.html|title=Google balances privacy, reach (including Erik Schmidt's personal information)|publisher=CNET|date=July 14, 2005| accessdate=August 19, 2010}} All the information had been gleaned from Google searches.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/google-chief-my-fears-for-generation-facebook-2055390.html|title=Interview to E. Schmidt|publisher=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=August 19, 2010|location=London |first=Jerome|last=Taylor|date=August 18, 2010}}{{cite news|url= http://money.cnn.com/2005/08/05/technology/google_cnet/|title=CNET: We've been blackballed by Google|publisher=CNN|date=August 5, 2005|accessdate=August 19, 2010}} On October 10, 2006, Shelby Bonnie resigned as chairman and [[chief executive officer|CEO]], in addition to two other executives, as a result of a [[options backdating|stock options backdating]] scandal that occurred between 1996 and 2003.{{cite web|url= http://edgar.secdatabase.com/2015/119312506206248/filing-main.htm|title=CNET Networks, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Oct 11, 2006|publisher=secdatabase.com|accessdate= Mar 27, 2013}} This would also cause the firm to restate its financial earnings over 1996 through 2003 for over $105 million in resulting expenses.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/30/technology/30options.html|title=CNet Restatement Goes Back to 1996|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=Dec 17, 2013}} The Securities and Exchange Commission later dropped an investigation into the practice. Neil Ashe was named as the new CEO.{{cite news|url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/news/2006-10-11-cnet-ceo_x.htm|title=CNET completes options review, CEO resigns|publisher=Reuters|date=October 11, 2006|accessdate= December 17, 2012}}{{cite journal|url= http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/cnet_avoids_backdating_charges/|title=CNET Avoids Backdating Charges|publisher=[[Aba Journal]]|date=November 5, 2011|accessdate=July 8, 2011}}{{citation|url=http://adage.com/article/digital/stock-option-backdating-claims-cnet-s-ceo/112445/|title=Stock-Option Backdating Claims CNet's CEO|publisher= AdAge|date=October 11, 2006|accessdate=July 8, 2011}} In 2011, CNET and CBS Interactive were sued by a coalition of artists (led by FilmOn founder Alki David) for copyright infringement by promoting the download of [[LimeWire]], a popular peer to peer downloading software.{{cite web|author=Albanesius, Chloe, PCMag.com |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2384913,00.asp |title=CBS, CNET Sued for Copyright Infringement Over LimeWire Distribution |publisher=[[PC Magazine]] |date=May 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324042850/http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0%2C2817%2C2384913%2C00.asp |archivedate=March 24, 2016 |df= }}{{cite web|author=Anderson, Nate, Ars Technica|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/05/cnet-sued-over-limewire-blamed-for-internet-piracy-phenomenon.ar|title=CNET sued over LimeWire, blamed for "Internet Piracy Phenomenon"|publisher=Ars Technica|date=May 4, 2011}} Although the original suit was voluntarily dropped by Alki David, he vowed to sue at a later date to bring "expanded"{{cite web|author=Sam Gustin |url=http://paidcontent.org/article/419-alki-david-drops-cnet-lawsuit-vows-to-bring-expanded-action/ |title=Alki David Drops CNET Lawsuit; Vows to Bring 'Expanded' Action |publisher=[[PaidContent]] |date=November 16, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108055848/http://paidcontent.org/article/419-alki-david-drops-cnet-lawsuit-vows-to-bring-expanded-action/ |archivedate=January 8, 2012 }} action against CBS Interactive. In November 2011, another lawsuit against CBS Interactive was introduced, claiming that CNET and CBS Interactive knowingly distributed LimeWire, the file sharing software.{{cite web|author=Ernesto, torrentfreak.com|url=http://torrentfreak.com/artists-sue-cbs-cnet-for-profiting-from-piracy-111115/|title=Artists Sue CBS, CNET, for Promoting and Profiting from Piracy|publisher=[[TorrentFreak]]|date=November 15, 2011}} ==Hopper controversy== In January 2013, CNET named [[Dish Network]]'s "Hopper with [[Slingbox|Sling]]" [[digital video recorder]] as a nominee for the [[International CES|CES]] "Best in Show" award (which is decided by CNET on behalf of its organizers), and named it the winner in a vote by the site's staff. However, CBS abruptly disqualified the Hopper, and vetoed the results because the company was in [[Auto Hop|active litigation]] with Dish Network. CNET also announced that it could no longer review any product or service provided by companies that CBS are in litigation with (which also includes [[Aereo]]). The new vote subsequently gave the Best in Show award to the [[Razer USA|Razer Edge]] tablet instead.{{cite web|title=Dish Recorder Snubbed for CNET Award Over CBS Legal Scuffle|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2013/01/10/dish-recorder-snubbed-for-cnet-award-over-cbs-legal-scuffle/|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=11 January 2013}} Dish Network's CEO Joe Clayton said that the company was "saddened that CNET’s staff is being denied its editorial independence because of CBS’ heavy-handed tactics." On January 14, 2013, editor-in-chief Lindsey Turrentine addressed the situation, stating that CNET's staff were in an "impossible" situation due to the [[conflict of interest]] posed by the situation, and promised that she would do everything within her power to prevent a similar incident from occurring again. The conflict also prompted one CNET senior writer, Greg Sandoval, to resign.{{cite web|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=CNET Picked Dish Hopper as 'Best of CES' ... Until CBS Stepped In|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2414276,00.asp |publisher=PC Magazine|accessdate=January 14, 2013}} The decision also drew the ire of staff from the [[Consumer Electronics Association]], the organizers of CES; CEO [[Gary Shapiro]] criticized the decision in a ''[[USA Today]]'' [[op-ed]] column and a statement by the CEA, stating that "making television easier to watch is not against the law. It is simply pro-innovation and pro-consumer." Shapiro felt that the decision also hurt the confidence of CNET's readers and staff, "destroying its reputation for editorial integrity in an attempt to eliminate a new market competitor." As a result of the controversy and fearing damage to the show's brand, the CEA announced on January 31, 2013 that CNET will no longer decide the CES Best in Show award winner due to the interference of CBS (the position has been offered to other technology publications), and the "Best in Show" award was jointly awarded to both the Hopper with Sling and Razer Edge.{{cite web|title=CNET loses CES awards following Dish Hopper controversy; DVR named 'Best In Show'|url= https://www.theverge.com/2013/1/31/3937476/cnet-loses-ces-awards-following-dish-hopper-controversy-dvr-named|publisher=[[The Verge]]|accessdate=January 31, 2013}} == Sections == === Reviews === : The reviews section of the site is the largest part of the site, and generates over 4,300 product and software reviews per year. The Reviews section also features Editors’ Choice Awards, which recognize products that are particularly innovative and of the highest quality. === News === : CNET News (formerly known as ''News.com''), launched in 1996, is a [[news]] website dedicated to technology, and was one of the first news sources to help define technology reporting in the age of the internet. CNET News has won several prestigious awards, including the [[National Magazine Awards|National Magazine award]].{{cite news|url= http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20040505005939/en/CNET-News.com-Wins-Coveted-National-Magazine-Award|title=CNET News.com Wins Coveted National Magazine Award for General Excellence Online|publisher=[[Business Wire]]|date=May 5, 2004|accessdate=January 31, 2014}} Content is created by both CNET and external media agencies as news articles and [[blog]]s, including ''Webware'' (Web 2.0 topics) and ''Crave'' (gadgets). === Video === {{main|CNET Video}} : [[CNET Video]] is CNET's Internet video channel offering a selection of on-demand video content including video reviews, first looks and special features. CNET Video plays various videos, including CNET video reviews. CNET editors such as [[Brian Cooley]], Jeff Bakalar, [[Bridget Carey]] and Brian Tong host shows like Car Tech, The 404 Show, Quick Tips, CNET Top 5, Update, The Apple Byte, video prizefights, and others, as well as special reports and reviews. On April 12, 2007, CNET Video aired its first episode of CNET LIVE, hosted by Brian Cooley and Tom Merritt. The first episode featured [[Justin Kan]] of [[justin.tv]].{{cite web|url=http://cnettv.cnet.com/8301-13415_53-9708591-11.html?tag=mncol;title|title=Wrap it up|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://cnettv.cnet.com/2001-1_53-27077.html|title=CNET Live: April 12, 2007 video|publisher=}} CNET Video was formerly known as CNET TV. === How To === : Officially launched August 2011, How To is the learning area of CNET providing tutorials, guides and tips for technology users. ==See also== * [[CBS Corporation]] * [[ZDNet]] * [[TechRepublic]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.cnet.com/}} {{CBS Interactive}} [[Category:American websites]] [[Category:CNET| ]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Technology websites]] [[Category:Webby Award winners]] [[Category:CBS Interactive websites]]
